themes.label: Decrees
themes.rationale: The text follows the standard formula for a decree issued by a collective body, beginning with the archon's name and the phrase 'it seemed good to the thiasotai'.

themes.label: Honorific Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The inscription honors Stephanos for his service as a supervisor and sacred official, citing his love of honor (philotimia) and goodness (andragathia).
themes.quote: ἐπαινέσαι Στέφανον τὸν ἐπιμελητήν φιλοτιμίας ἕνεκεν καὶ ἀνδραγαθίας

themes.label: Votive Dedications
themes.rationale: The decree concludes with instructions for the honoree to set up a dedication (anathema) in the sanctuary of the goddess using a monetary award.

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: The text refers to the act of inscribing the decree on stone for public display, implying a stone stele.

persons.name: Stephanos
persons.role: Honoree, official (epimeletes and hieropoios), breastplate-maker, and miller

rationale: This document records three consecutive annual decrees (302/1–300/299 BC) by an Athenian thiasos (religious association) honoring a member named Stephanos. Stephanos, identified as both a breastplate-maker and a miller, is praised for his service as a supervisor and sacred official, specifically for his care of sacrifices and processions for Aphrodite and Demeter. The text illustrates the internal administration of private cultic groups in early Hellenistic Athens, including the awarding of crowns and the requirement to set up a stone dedication.
